title: Bilateral Sensorineural Hearing Loss with Strong Family History
chief_complaint: I have had hearing loss in both ears for about 10 years, but I've noticed it's getting harder to understand soft speech at home and at work.

problem_summary.functional_impact: Increased difficulty understanding soft speech in daily environments.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking first hearing examination due to functional difficulties.

history.present_illness: Patient reports a 10-year history of bilateral hearing loss. This is her first hearing examination.
history.otologic_history: No reported history of ear pathology or ear surgery. Denies tinnitus or dizziness.
history.medical_psych_history: Significant family history of hearing loss: mother, maternal aunt, one sibling, and a son all have varying degrees of hearing loss.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Right ear shows normal sensitivity 250-1000 Hz, sloping to moderate at 3000-6000 Hz, rising to mild at 8000 Hz. Left ear shows normal sensitivity 250-1000 Hz, sloping to mild/moderate in the high frequencies.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Reception Thresholds (SRT) are in agreement with Pure Tone Averages (PTA). Word Recognition Scores (WRS) are excellent bilaterally at suprathreshold levels.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal tympanograms (Type A) bilaterally, indicating normal middle ear function.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral, sloping sensorineural hearing loss. Low-frequency hearing is preserved (normal), while high frequencies slope to a mild-to-moderate degree. Speech discrimination is excellent bilaterally. The configuration and history are consistent with a hereditary etiology given the strong family history and lack of noise exposure or other pathology.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows you hear low pitches (like vowels) well, but have difficulty with high pitches (like consonants s, f, th). This explains why you struggle with soft speech.
The type of hearing loss is sensorineural (permanent nerve loss). Given your strong family history and lack of noise exposure, this is likely genetic.
Your ability to understand speech remains excellent when the volume is loud enough.
You are a good candidate for amplification (hearing aids) to help with the high-frequency sounds you are missing.
We recommend annual testing to monitor your hearing, as well as using hearing protection in noisy environments to preserve your remaining hearing.
